6 hours per week

15-20 hrs (more than 10 reading assignments a week, sometimes up to 50)

The first few weeks the workload was about 15 hours/week but as the instructor was constantly adding more random readings and without a structure to the class, I gave up and only read when we had write-ups.
3 - 5 hours
A lot of reading, which I honestly didn't always do. I'd say maybe around 8 hrs of work per week.
Lots of time reading, but this was largely due to my limited prior knowledge. I dedicated about 7 hours a week to reading. Additional time was spent writing papers.

The course title was misleading. I was expecting the course to be more analytical in its approach. Additionally, I felt like the instructor did not lecture enough. Too much of class time was taken up by student presentations and group activities. I would have much rather learned more about the Professors work and experiences. The class was also very redundant. For almost half the semester, we followed the same format each week with a different country.
I included course feedback in separate email to Dr. Hecht.

STRENGTHS: Great instructor who is always willing to help students, great TAs who were always available to meet, good class material 

WEAKNESSES: far too much reading assigned for a single class, especially if expected to complete all readings

I think the class was informative.  I think it was a little scattered-- it tried to be a lot of things and could benefit by being more focused. I would recommend varying the group discussions, more one-pagers, and less reading overall.
The class is pretty practical. Students' presentation is a good way to summarise the study materials but occupied too many class time.

TFs play an important role in the class.  

Saw one of the TFs' presentation in another class.  She just wasn't qualified to grade our presentations.
The course is very informative and helpful. It is also well defined and clearly structured.

The course was not taught as advertised in the course description.  It looked at advanced topics that really made the class not suitable as an introduction to health systems.  The reading load was extreme and often consisted of hundreds of pages.  There was no prioritization of the reading material and we often had little more than surface level discussion about it come class time.  We had group presentations every week which took up at least 30 minutes of each class.  I did not find these as a useful tool for learning as the student presenters often knew little more about the topic than the rest of the class (this was only because the topics were so vast, it is impossible for a group to understand it in a short period of time). 
This class made me change my mind about pursuing a global health concentration.

I enjoyed this course. I did feel like I learned more about how to think about health systems nationally and from an economic perspective, which I had little experience with before taking this class. However, I really wanted to get more out of it than a largely economic viewpoint. I wish we had learned more about epidemiology as well as *how* to implement the strategies we so often talked about.

Wonderful course! I like that it started with broad concepts before moving to case studies. Case studies were heavily focused on infectious disease, which might be good to change in future iterations of the course. Readings were heavy each week, it might be good to focus them a bit more or use one or two focus readings. It would be helpful to have more advance notice about what group we were in for discussion. I thought ilthe class was a fantastic capstone for the global health concentration

I loved the student presentations - they were very well prepared and informative. I also learned a lot from the way Prof. Hecht approached past cases / program modeling. The course could be improved by having one week that walks us through how a case was approached and giving an overview of how the modeling was conceptualized. Overall it was a very enjoyable course and I learned a lot about health systems reform.

Since this was the first year this class was taught, it seemed very unorganized and all over the place. After we finished covering UHC it seemed like we just jumped around from topic to topic. It's also completely unreasonable to assign so much reading--no one can get through 300+ pages per week while also juggling four other classes. It's also unfair to assign more readings the day before class.

A lot of feedbacks were already discussed on the last day of class, but I think the class could improve if the class has a clear focus and realistic amount of reading materials assigned to students. Also, we often felt that we were rushed with time. If all the materials are to be covered with the same amount of expectation, I recommend longer class time or cutting some of the expectation.
The strength is that the class covers a very important topic for students in public health and global health.

The course allowed me to learn quite a lot about countries' heath systems, and scale-up of certain programs. However, I wish there was more of a technical component. I also felt as if there wasn't enough assigned--maybe more shorter, frequent essays?

This class was a bit disorganized, but I think only because it was the first time being offered. I thought student presentations went on much too longoften leaving no time for Professor Hechts lecture on the subject. Hearing more from Professor Hecht, and less from fellow students who are presenting on the same readings we all did, would be more valuable. Also, the readings were very long and did not include much guidance, in the sense that it was hard to filter through all the pages to find what was most important to know. It would be helpful to assign more concise readings, or highlight topics that we should focus on.
I wish we had more one pagers, and more focused reading assignments/class debates

I liked the topics we covered and the cases. I wish instead of student presentations we had presented cases for different countries. I also wish the class had been smaller. Another thing that I had wished was the class was structured as if we were public health professionals. I was hoping to have a feel for what it would be like if I were to be working with an international organization (i.e. the UN or WHO or the World Bank) or governmental position. Either that or I had wished we went into more depth on the tools we had discussed in class. I thought it was too much of a brief overview of what skills were important because we covered so many of them. While I do know that there are classes like cost-effectiveness offered but some students are unable to take those classes. It would have been nice to have an idea of how those tools are done.
This was a good introduction to the practice of global health and applicable policy and economic strategies.
I felt I was learning more from the students and less from the professor himself.

Strengths- Professor Hecht's PowerPoint presentations on investment cases and scaling up methods were very helpful to understand how consulting companies work in a global health context. More real world application by asking us to replicate the presentation with our own global health issue would have made the course engaging and interesting.

Weaknesses- I did not gain any substantial knowledge from this course. It clarified my understanding of how UN agencies work and what efforts they make in scaling up UHC globally, but the class quickly became repetitive after the first two weeks. I expected to gain more technical skill rather than textbook knowledge of how these organizations work. The midterm and final exams did not truly test my knowledge of any of the course material- they were summaries of papers already written, which felt like a waste of time. I did not feel challenged throughout the course. The group assignments throughout class time were the worst and the debates were lackluster.

Too much reading, not enough guidance in preparing for class. Instead of breakout groups every week, I think I would have gotten more out of fewer breakout sessions with more detail (like consulting-style case studies).

Strengths: The professor; interesting to learn about different countries experiences; interesting readings. 
Weaknesses: not a substantive learning experience. Could be more technical and focused. Class presentations take up a lot of the class, not sure this is the most interesting, as presentations just summarize the readings. 

To improve, a more structure lecture could be more enriching--including more skills- and knowledge-building. The readings are excessive, there is no way anyone can go through all of them. If the class is going to focus on discussing the readings then students must be able to read them thoroughly to have an enriching discussion. This is not feasible with the amount of readings (sometimes 10 or more readings each week). Instead of student presentations, it would be better to have groups assigned to read a smaller amount of readings on one specific issue, and then have a discussion in plenary. Group exercises do not usually work in such a mixed and large class. Quality instead of quantity in terms of the amount of content the course covers would also improve its quality. Likewise, regarding the professor's presentations, teaching and discussing the process and methods, rather than just presenting results would make the class more substantive.

The course is new, and had much to be improved upon. Clarify which readings are important/take priority, communicate course and assignment expectations, and manage time in the classroom more efficiently for effective learning. There would be discussion time set aside in lecture but it wasn't very effective in facilitating dialogue and would result in unprofessional debates. Instead of 2-hr lecture once a week, have 2 days of classroom time: 1-hr for lecture, 1-hr for group discussion/scheduled debates. I also recommend final presentations and that they be accompanied by a final paper that relates to the presentation students presented on. Lastly, practice makes for progress, and having more frequent 1-pagers will foster student success.

My overall assessment of the course is below average to poor. This course was the ONLY YSPH course I was thrilled to take and excited to learn more. However, as much excited as I was, I was disappointed. I thought the course was going to be empowering, where I was learn from world leader such as our instructor and learn tools and actually practice coming up with a health care system reform through our exercises. in return, I had to sit in class hear the presentations the others present (who by the way only chose a portion of the readings to talk about) and do useless debates where we came up with the same answers week after week. I understand that the class might have seen conversational but that was not what I was looking for. I didn't want the students to summarize the readings but the instructor as us and walk us step by step on why the reform of that country was a success or a failure. Prof Hecht has such an amazing work experience that I wish he shared and inspired us. in the ideal world, i would have this class designed as one of the HBS case classes where the instructor picks ONE case (at most two main case), we read and together we go over the strengths and ways we would have improved that reform. while it was interesting to learn more about other countries reform, I honestly don't think I got any new competencies or skills out of this class that I didn't know before. Another weakness of this class is their class policy. while I understand that this was the first time the course was taught, it is not fair to the students to change the policies such as class attendance drastically AFTER the DROP-OUT period ended. Fall semester was the time when most of my interviews happened and they are set on a date that cannot be changed. it will not be fair to lose half the participation grade if you miss a second class. please understand that this is an elective course and not a core course, so students find the subject attractive enough to take the course, therefore such stick policy is just not fair.

The course set up appeared to be very interesting, but was clearly not designed for a large class size which resulted in poor execution. However, the material was interesting and had the class flowed they way it had originally been intended I think I would be more enthusiastic about it.

The course has a lot of kinks to work out since it is new. I wished there was a weekly summary assignment to ensure that everyone read and enrich the class discussion.  Only comment is to be more upfront about assignment expectations and grading. Grading rubric was not clear to me.
Wasn't what was expected from the title. Was expecting it to be more quant based and unfortunately it was not. Too broad overview of global health, overlapping Chimas course.

Great course. Very insightful. Material was good. The course's downfall was the organization. It appeared very thrown together. Decisions that should have been published in the syllabus were emailed the night before a lecture.

This is a fantastic course. Professor Hecht has a broad experience in the field of UHC reform, which he brings to the table. He is a deeply caring individual who clearly wants the best for his students. He is encouraging, supportive and kind. 

His teaching assistants were brilliant - yes, their marking was tough, but they provide detail feedback to ensure continued improvement. 

I made great strides in this course, both in my ability to think about different perspectives and convey this understanding on paper. 

This course was transformative.

I think Professor Hecht is a good professor and that he cares about his students. The class obviously has some kinks to be worked out, but it has promise for next year. Professor Hecht should definitely modify his teaching style, especially if the class size remains large. Additionally, I felt that the professor had a tendency to dismiss opinions from people who were clearly American and favor the opinions of those not brought up in the United States.

Exceptional instructor, course would have been better suited to a smaller group but he managed the classroom size effectively.  I'd encourage him to bring more of his personal experiences into the instruction in future courses.  I can appreciate that at times it may feel uncomfortable talking about all of your own experiences however as a class I think we all would have really appreciated that insight.
Wonderful instructor! You could tell he was very passionate about his work and working with students.
Good-- would love to hear more about his personal experiences and be more focused on specific case studies.
He is inspired and kind. But I would expect to hear more case decision or experience from him.
He only teaches 20 minutes per day.  Otherwise, he has us do pointless group discussions.
Prof. Hecht is a great instructor. I particularly like the way Prof. Hecht shared his own work in global health.

Dr. Hecht has obviously had a very accomplished global health career and has much to teach his students.  However, I felt his teaching style unfortunately missed this opportunity.  Global health concepts were vague and abstract with very few "real world" examples.  Lots of important questions about global health systems were presented, but how to answer them was rarely taught.  Reflecting on the course, I don't know if I learned any useful tools for addressing the most common problems many LMIC face.

I enjoyed Professor Hecht's lectures and particularly his commitment to group activities and debates in class. However, I wish he had spoken more about his personal experience, which seems very valuable given his work history. I also felt like he was a bit out of touch about how much work he was giving us and how much free time he thought we had. He often assigned several hundred pages of dense reading per week, adding extra readings late the night before class. As someone with an epidemiology background and little experience with health systems/economics/policy, I struggled quite a bit to understand the readings and figure out how to navigate assignments.
Experienced, intelligent, responsive. Cares about his students!

Professor Hecht is a very engaging and approachable professor. He was open to questions and did a wonderful job facilitating class discussion. I especially enjoyed learning about his past work and hearing the presentations from real projects that he consulted on.
I feel very lucky to have learned from Professor Hecht but I wish he had been more organized. I liked the small group discussions we had in class but we always went over time which was frustrating.
Great professor and lecturer. Very receptive to feedback, and I am interested in seeing how this course will develop throughout the years.
Prof Hecht was very knowledgeable and passionate about his work.  However, it would have been helpful if he was more responsive to communications and more organized with assignments.

I expected this class to be eye-opening and engaging but it fell flat. I think Professor Hecht did his best to involve the 40 people in the course, but the execution was poor. As an individual with over 20 years of experience in global health, I would have loved to hear more about Hecht's experience working for UN agencies rather than the surface level approach he took. These organizations are complex and rife with bureaucracy, and we would have benefited if Hecht taught us how to navigate organizational politics through innovation and entrepreneurship, as he has done. The group assignments are useless and should be removed from the next curriculum. More long-term group projects (like an investment case for a Ministry of Finance or Health) would help us better understand the material and the complicated relationships government agencies have.
Very knowledgeable. I wish he did more to connect his real world experiences to what we discussed in class.

Strengths: The professor is very knowledgeable and passionate. Very engaged with students.   
Weaknesses: More structure and in-depth learning and analysis will be ideal.
As helpful as his intentions were, his busy schedule seemed to detract from his ability to give timely attention and feedback to student concerns and assignments.

The instructor has an impressive career background; however didn't know how to design this course properly. the subject is similar to other courses but what could have made his class more interesting was if he took the lead to teach instead of facilitating the students while they taught the class materials.

The professor was responsive to student feedback which I greatly appreciated. However, I do think the amount of literature assigned was overwhelming, especially when you have four other classes to be reading for. Towards the end of the semester I began to skim the papers to be able to have time to complete written assignments in time. I also found his insight on global health policy making very interesting and would encourage him to make time in each class to give a bit of a lecture prior to the group discussions to help guide students in the right direction. Additionally, I would also strongly encourage that only a select number of readings be required and the rest optional to also help with the large workload.
He was great, it was nice to hear about some of his work. Great flexibility and responsiveness to student feedback.
Prof. Hecht is a great instructor. I just think he can introduce more about his work and give himself more time.
Cool guy, has incredibly vast experience and all about the data. Sadly, we were not taught how to find that data or analyze it appropriately.
Excellent. Very willing to work with students. Great background.
As above
I would only recommend this course if large structural changes were made. As is, I would not recommend.

Interesting course, engaging readings and exceptional instructor.  This was the first year Dr. Hecht taught the class, I'd love to see what it looks like in future years as he incorporates some of the feedback from this initial session.

Served as a great introduction to global health reform issues with expertly curated readings to help guide student's learning.
Overall, it was a great course with lots of applicable and real-world concepts. However, the reading workload was far too much considering students have other classes to focus on.

This class would be better for the second year students with policy background.
It gives a board view of reforming health system and practice the concepts in country case studies.

The worst cost-benefit trade-off - if your expectation is to learn from Prof Hecht.  TFs, who know the materials as much as the rest of us, somehow end up leading class discussions and grade our work.  No wonder YSPH doesn't rank high.
Highly recommend it.

What I got out of this course was a better understanding of how to go through national data, policy briefs, and implementation reports, and use this information to generate my own ideas and suggestions about policies/interventions. I wish I had learned more about implementation and epidemiology; however, this course was still fun and informative, and I would recommend it to other students (provided they read the syllabus first so they understand what the course is actually about).

I would recommend this course to a fellow student if they want to learn more about health system reform is approached and how to critically asses program scale-ups. Class itself was very engaging and enjoyable and the assignments were purposeful. You learn a lot from your classmates and from the work experiences of Professor Hecht in the field. It was a great course!

This is essentially a case studies class that naturally attracts obnoxious people who think their opinion is more important than everyone else's. Be ready for 300+ pages of reading per week and presentations and papers that focus on these readings.

I recommend this course if it improves its curriculum from student facilitated presentation and case study to more instructor's interpretation of the topics and case study focused classes. The topic is very important and interesting especially for future students in global health.
Great overview of international health systems, If youve worked in the field before
This course can be very interesting, but if you truly want a structured learning experience, maybe an alternative would be a better idea.

I would not recommend this course if it remains in the same format. Given this was the first time this course was taught at YSPH, I think Professor Hecht will make the course more productive for the future class, as he was very receptive to our in-class feedback. If the course changes and becomes more hands-on, I can see it becoming very beneficial and popular at YSPH.
I don't know if I would recommend the course as I took it, but I think some changes will be made for next year, in which case I would consider it.

Since this is the first time the class is being taught, there is a lot of room for improvement. However, I am sure the class will improve significantly next year and it is a class worth taking. It is one of the very few global courses in YSPH and hopefully it will become one of the strongest.
The course is great in theory, but the student experience is not reflected on the promises of the syllabus. If improvements are made, then I might recommend the course.
Unless the class changes the current structure, I would NOT recommend this course to other students. The prior reasons mentioned on Q6 and 7 give the reasons why.

Overall, the course load was just a bit heavy because of the frequent 5-7 weekly readings which sometime could amount to 50+ pages of reading, but was still satisfactorily interesting. Considering this was the first time the course was taught, it was an excellent beginning, There are few things that need to be changed, but the professor has been very receptive to feedback and definitely can see the course improving,
Very broad overview of global health expecting it to be revised in the future and be more data focused. Yes for those SERIOUSLY interested in global health who havent taken Chimas.
Needs to be better organized. Then I would strongly recommend it.
As above
